Why $OKLO Is A Long-Term Stock To Watch 👇

Artificial intelligence is taking over everything. From ChatGPT’s mind-blowing conversations to machine learning driving cars, AI is the new electricity. But here’s what no one talks about: AI doesn’t just run on code. It runs on energy. And tons of it.

Training AI models like ChatGPT uses as much energy as 180,000 homes every day. Each interaction with it? The cooling alone takes the energy equivalent of eight water bottles. As AI adoption explodes, the demand for clean, scalable energy is already a huge problem.

This is why I’m excited about nuclear energy. It’s not intermittent like wind or solar, and it doesn’t pollute like fossil fuels. It’s clean, reliable, and produces massive output. And $OKLO is leading the charge with its micro-reactors.

Let’s talk about why I think $OKLO is one of the most interesting long-term plays.

Oklo’s leadership team is what got my attention. Jacob DeWitte, the CEO, is a nuclear engineer who’s not just academic, but he’s a builder. His mission is clear: make nuclear energy safe, clean, and available to everyone. 

Then there’s Sam Altman. You know the name because he co-founded OpenAI, the team behind $MSFT-backed ChatGPT. When Altman throws his weight behind $OKLO, it’s not random. He’s connecting the dots between AI’s exploding energy needs and nuclear’s ability to deliver. It’s a huge signal.

There’s also Chris Wright on the board. He’s not just an energy veteran, he’s going to be President Trump’s pick for Secretary of Energy if Trump wins. That kind of policy influence could change the nuclear game, and $OKLO would benefit directly.

Oklo’s tech is a game-changer. Their Aurora Powerhouse isn’t a traditional nuclear plant. It’s a micro-reactor about the size of a basketball court. It can go anywhere—urban areas, remote locations, even next to AI data centers. It runs for 20 years without refueling. Twenty years. Compare that to traditional reactors that need refueling every couple of years. It also uses a passive cooling system, so it doesn’t rely on external power or water. It’s safe by design.

But here’s the part that really caught my eye. $OKLO’s reactors can run on nuclear waste. Think about that. What other industry takes its biggest problem and turns it into fuel?

The connection between AI and $OKLO couldn’t be clearer. AI’s biggest bottleneck isn’t innovation—it’s energy. Data centers are energy hogs. $GOOGL, $AMZN, and $MSFT are all racing to meet AI demands, and energy costs are a massive factor. $OKLO’s micro-reactors solve this with localized, uninterrupted, clean energy.

I’m not saying $OKLO is a risk-free investment. It’s early. 

Revenue isn’t expected until 2027, and scaling nuclear tech isn’t easy. There are regulatory hurdles, public skepticism, and competition from other nuclear innovators like TerraPower, backed by Bill Gates. But that’s also why there’s an opportunity.

The U.S. Department of Energy has already validated $OKLO’s tech with a 20-year power purchase agreement for its first site. Globally, nuclear energy is making a comeback. France is building six new reactors by 2050. China plans to build 150 over the next 15 years. Even the U.S. is finally pushing nuclear forward, with tax credits for advanced reactors under the Inflation Reduction Act.

Here’s where I’m at. I see $OKLO as a long-term play. 

I’m personally only interested in single-digit prices because this is still speculative. 

But for those willing to wait, I think the payoff could be massive. AI is here to stay, and energy is its lifeblood. $OKLO isn’t just meeting that demand—it’s redefining how it’s done.

This isn’t just a stock. It’s a bet on the future of energy and innovation. If you’re watching from the sidelines, the FOMO is only getting started.

Why $RKLB Is A Long Term Stock To Watch👇
  
I’ve been keeping a close eye on $RKLB, and it’s quickly becoming one of my favorite growth stories in the market.

Space is no longer just a dream. It’s a rapidly growing economy, and Rocket Lab is positioned right at the center of it.

Their Electron rocket has already made waves, with over 50 successful missions and nearly 200 satellites deployed. But what really has me excited is the Neutron rocket.

This isn’t just an upgrade. It’s a move into an entirely new market.

Neutron is designed for medium-lift payloads, a segment that’s been completely underserved. Companies like $TSLA-backed Starlink and $AMZN’s Project Kuiper are racing to deploy thousands of satellites, and $RKLB is ready to meet that demand.

These constellations are going to need reliable and efficient launches, and Neutron is stepping up at exactly the right time.

Defense spending is another huge factor driving $RKLB’s growth.

They’ve already secured a $515 million contract with the U.S. Space Development Agency to build a secure satellite constellation. That’s not just a big win. It’s a sign that Rocket Lab is being trusted with critical national security projects.

And then there’s their collaboration with U.S. Transportation Command to explore rocket-powered cargo delivery. If this becomes viable, it could completely change how global logistics works, slashing shipping times from days to hours.

What sets $RKLB apart for me is how they’ve diversified beyond launches.

Their Space Systems division has become a powerhouse of its own, focusing on satellite manufacturing, in-orbit servicing, propulsion systems, and even advanced solar panels for satellites.

That part of their business grew 81% year-over-year. They’ve created multiple revenue streams, which makes them a much more resilient company in an industry where many players rely on just one thing.

People always ask about competition, and it’s a fair question.

Yes, $SPACEX dominates the headlines, but they’re focused on heavy-lift rockets like Starship. $RKLB has carved out its own niche with small and medium payloads, where they’re clearly a leader.

Other companies like $SPCE and $ASTR are still trying to prove themselves, but $RKLB’s track record gives them a major edge.

I think the most impressive thing about Rocket Lab is how forward-thinking they are.

They’re not just launching rockets. They’re innovating across the entire space economy.

Their Photon spacecraft platform is already supporting NASA’s Artemis program and upcoming lunar missions.

On top of that, their work on solar panels for satellites opens up another exciting growth area.

When I look at the financials, I see a company making the right moves.

They’ve posted record revenue and are improving margins while heavily investing in the future, particularly the Neutron rocket and their expanding Space Systems division.

They’re not profitable yet, but that’s the nature of growth stocks.

For me, this is about the long-term potential, not just the next quarter.

I’m approaching $RKLB the same way I do with any growth stock.

I’m not chasing it at any price.

I prefer to wait for discounts and buy during pullbacks, which I think will offer plenty of opportunities along the way.

Rocket Lab has already shown they can execute, and they’re stepping into markets that will define the future of space.

For anyone watching the growth of the space economy, $RKLB is a company to keep on your radar.

This chart presents a problem for the U.S. oil market. 

Despite production reaching record highs of 13,481 thousand barrels per day, the number of active rigs continues to decline, now standing at just 424. 

Historically, when rig counts drop, production eventually follows. However, today’s advanced drilling techniques and efficiency gains have allowed companies to sustain output with fewer rigs. 

While this may seem like a win for now, it poses a significant challenge for future supply.

The Long-Term Problem:

Oil wells do not last forever. Shale wells, in particular, experience rapid decline rates. Without reinvestment in new drilling, production will eventually decrease. 

The continued decline in rig counts suggests that companies are not allocating capital to long-term sustainability. 

This could result in a major supply crunch in the coming years, potentially pushing oil prices significantly higher.

In previous cycles, such as in 2015 and 2019, falling rig counts led to a delayed decline in production. 

If the same pattern holds, the current divergence could mean that in a few years, oil prices will rise sharply, contributing to inflation and increasing energy costs for businesses and consumers.

The Short-Term Problem: 

In the short term, American oil companies have little interest in increasing drilling activity. The reason is simple. It does not make sense for them financially. 

With oil prices around $75 per barrel, these companies are making substantial profits without the need to spend heavily on new drilling projects. 

At the same time, gas prices remain relatively inexpensive for Americans, currently around $2.90 per gallon.
Oil prices are determined by supply and demand. 

If American oil companies ramp up drilling activity, as President Trump has proposed, the increased supply would push oil prices lower. 

While this would benefit consumers by lowering gas prices, it would reduce profits for oil companies. 

Despite having 9,000 approved permits available for drilling, companies are choosing not to use them. The demand for oil remains stable, especially in the current strong economy. 

For oil companies, it is more profitable to maintain current production levels rather than flood the market with additional supply.

From a policy standpoint, it makes sense for the White House to push for more drilling to keep gas prices low and maintain energy independence. 

However, oil companies are primarily driven by profit motives and have no incentive to expand drilling efforts under the current conditions.

With all the talk about tariffs this weekend, there’s one trade issue that isn’t getting enough attention: the de minimis loophole.

This exemption allows any shipment under $800 to enter the U.S. without paying import duties, undergoing customs inspections, or complying with many regulatory standards.

It was introduced in the 1930s—long before e-commerce—and was never designed for a world where companies could exploit it at scale.

Today, that is exactly what’s happening.

Last year alone, nearly one billion packages entered the U.S. from China under this loophole.

Because Customs and Border Protection cannot possibly inspect goods at this volume, many shipments slip through the cracks.

This allows companies to avoid tariffs entirely by breaking up large orders into multiple smaller shipments, effectively bypassing traditional import duties.

In 2022, for example, GAP paid $700 million in import taxes, while H&M paid $200 million.

Meanwhile, Temu, which heavily benefits from this loophole, paid zero.

This isn’t just a tax issue.

It creates an unfair advantage that distorts competition, letting overseas sellers price their products lower than U.S. retailers who must comply with the full cost of doing business.

Beyond tariff evasion, de minimis shipments present a significant consumer safety risk.

Unlike standard imports, these packages do not undergo rigorous safety checks, making it easier for counterfeit goods, mislabeled products, and even hazardous materials to enter the market undetected.

A November 2024 report found toxic substances, including lead, in children’s products from Temu and AliExpress.

One jacket contained 622 times the legal limit of toxic chemicals.

While U.S. companies are held to strict product safety standards, many of these direct-to-consumer imports face little to no oversight.

The financial impact is just as concerning.

Because companies that use the de minimis loophole avoid paying import duties, the U.S. government loses billions in potential revenue each year.

Meanwhile, American businesses and taxpayers bear the financial burden.

Companies like Temu and SHEIN operate under an unfair trade advantage, undercutting domestic competitors who must follow the rules.

This is not about shutting down global trade.

It is about ensuring a level playing field.

As discussions around tariffs heat up, the de minimis loophole deserves far more attention.

Free trade isn’t free when it allows unchecked imports to flood the market while U.S. businesses are forced to compete with a built-in disadvantage.

The greatest investor of all time:

Warren Buffett.

He built one of the most successful investment track records in history.

And he famously said, “The stock market is designed to transfer money from the active to the patient.”

Here are 10 of his teachings on investing that changed my life:

1. Be Greedy When Others Are Fearful

“The best opportunities come when everyone else is panicking.”

Market crashes feel terrifying, but they create generational wealth.

When others are selling great businesses at a discount, that’s when you should be buying.

2. Buy Wonderful Businesses at Fair Prices

“It’s far better to buy a wonderful company at a fair price than a fair company at a wonderful price.”

Cheap stocks aren’t always good stocks.

Focus on quality businesses with strong fundamentals that will compound over time.

3. Time in the Market Beats Timing the Market

“No one can predict short-term movements, but over time, the market goes up.”

Trying to perfectly time the top or bottom is a losing game.

Consistently investing in great businesses beats jumping in and out of the market.

4. Avoid Businesses That Require Perfect Execution

“A truly great business must have an enduring ‘moat’ that protects excellent returns on invested capital.”

If a company needs flawless execution to succeed, it’s not a great investment.

The best businesses can survive and thrive even when things don’t go perfectly.

5. Never Risk Permanent Loss

“The first rule of an investment is don’t lose money. The second rule is don’t forget the first rule.”

Protecting your downside is just as important as maximizing your upside.

A few bad decisions can wipe out years of gains.

6. Cash Flow Is Everything

“Accounting is the language of business.”

Profits can be manipulated.

Cash flow tells the real story.

7. A Small, Focused Portfolio Beats Over-Diversification

“Wide diversification is only required when investors do not understand what they are doing.”

Owning too many stocks can dilute your returns.

Focus on businesses you truly understand.

8. Look for Companies With Deep Moats

“The key to investing is determining the competitive advantage of any given company.”

The best investments are hard to compete with.

Find companies with pricing power, brand strength, and an unshakable market position.

9. Compounding Is the Real Cheat Code

“My wealth has come from a combination of living in America, some lucky genes, and compound interest.”

Small, consistent gains snowball into life-changing wealth.

Give compounding enough time, and the results will shock you.

10. Patience Is the Ultimate Investing Edge

“The stock market is a device for transferring money from the impatient to the patient.”

Most investors fail not because they’re wrong—but because they can’t sit still.

Buffett didn’t get rich chasing trends.

He got rich by mastering these principles and repeating them for decades.
